facts.text: Elections to the Delhi Municipal Corporation were held on May 2, 1973.
Appellant Benarsi Dass secured 3974 valid votes as against 3882 valid votes obtained by Respondent 1 Sumer Chand from Ward No. [unspecified], and appellant was declared duly elected.

Respondent 1 filed an election petition under S.15 of the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 before the Election Tribunal (District Judge) to challenge the election inter alia on the ground of corrupt practices particularised in para 9 of the petition, praying for declaration that the election of the returned candidate be void and that he be declared duly elected under S.19(1)(c).

In his written statement, the returned candidate (appellant) pleaded under Additional Pleas that the petitioner (Respondent 1) was guilty of corrupt practices particularised in the written statement and disentitled to be declared elected.
District Judge held that the appellant was not entitled to plead and prove that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practices.
Appellant filed writ application under Article 226 before Delhi High Court, which was dismissed by Single Judge.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 289 of 1972 dismissed by Division Bench of Delhi High Court, granting certificate under Article 133(1).

legal_issues.text: Whether in an election petition under the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 for getting an election declared void and for a further declaration that the petitioner himself had been duly elected, the returned candidate is entitled to plead and prove that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practice in the election in question, and was therefore not entitled to be declared as duly elected?

petitioner_arguments.text: Right to plead and prove that the election-petitioner was guilty of corrupt practice and disqualified under S.9(1)(d) of the Corporation Act to be declared duly elected; applies to all stages of election petition; stress on word 'being' in S.9(1)(d).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.9(1)(d) Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957; ubi jus ibi remedium; Mischief Rule (Heydon's case)

petitioner_arguments.text: If not permitted, returned candidate left without remedy due to finality under S.21; S.33 remedy circuitous.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.21, S.33 Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957

respondent_arguments.text: Plea is recrimination; no provision in Corporation Act analogous to S.97 Representation of the People Act, 1951; disqualification under S.9(1)(d) read with S.17(1)(a) must exist at date of poll.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: S.9(1)(d), S.17(1)(a) Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957; S.97 Representation of the People Act, 1951

respondent_arguments.text: Returned candidate's remedy is under S.33(3).

court_reasoning.text: Plea is recrimination akin to S.97 RP Act; no corresponding provision in Corporation Act; cannot spell out from S.9(1)(d) as 'found to have been guilty' means prior to election; strict construction of election law required.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Right to recriminate is statutory creature, not common law; court cannot supply omission.

court_reasoning.text: District Judge's inquiry limited to S.19(1) orders; in composite petition, only check majority of valid votes under S.19(2), not corrupt practices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Valid votes distinct from corrupt practices.

court_reasoning.text: Election contest statutory proceeding; no common law powers; cannot invoke ubi jus ibi remedium or mischief rule to supply casus omissus.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Courts averse to defeat justice on technicality but powers creature of statute.

holdings.text: Returned candidate not entitled to recriminate by pleading and proving corrupt practices by election-petitioner to prevent declaration of due election.

precedents_cited.case_name: P. Malai Chami v. M. Andi Ambalam
precedents_cited.relevance: Election contest statutory; strict construction; tribunal not inquisitorial.
Tribunal judicial, not inquisitorial; decides according to law.
Explains nature of recrimination under S.97 RP Act as inter-petition.
Mischief rule argued but not applied.
Meaning of 'have been' as immediately prior to specific time.

statutes_cited.name: Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs qualifications, disqualifications, election petitions, grounds for voiding elections, orders, recrimination absence.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions paralleled but S.97 recrimination absent in DMC Act.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences leading to disqualification under S.9 DMC Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied to trial of election petitions.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed affirming High Court view that returned candidate cannot recriminate under DMC Act absent provision like S.97 RP Act; desirability of amendment noted; hope expressed for prompt reference under S.33 if needed.

key_quotes.text: The principal question that falls to be determined in this appeal on certificate, is whether in an election petition under the Delhi Municipal Corporation Act, 1957 ... the returned candidate is entitled to plead and prove that the petitioner was guilty of corrupt practice...
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Statutory provisions of election law are to be strictly construed and its requirements strictly observed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key principle applied to deny recrimination.

key_quotes.text: What is sauce for the goose is sauce for the gander.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes purity of elections for all candidates.
